JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 6.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER

HOPKINS MAN PRESIDENT
Woodrow Wilson the Son of Many States and Many Institutions of
Learning, but Hopkins Claims a Share at Least of the
Honor Which Has Accrued to One of Her Ph. D.'s.
Woodrow Wilson, of Virginia,
Georgia, South Carolina, Maryland
and New Jersey, will be the eighth
president of the United States born
in the Old Dominion, that mother
of States and statesmen. He will
be the ninth Scotch-Irishman and
the first Johns Hopkins man upon
Whom the people of the United
States have conferred this high
honor and to whom they have confided this great trust. Yet he is
a man that belongs to no one small
locality, nor section, nor university.
For many States and schools have
had a part in his making, and he
is •a typical American of the substantial Scotch and English. stock
which furnished a large percentage
of eighteenth century immigration
to America and became so prominent in the winning of American
freedom. In a sense he may be
,said to epitomize the high moral
ideals arid purpose of the men and
women of the twentieth century,
and he has demonstrated, in his
person the power of progressive reform in politics in a State that had
developed some of the worst features of "practical politics" as
manipulated by the "boss."
Here in Baltimore, however, we
have always claimed him as a
"Hopkins man," and we were proud'
to do so because of his record as
a teacher of the 'science of politics
and the author of good books on
political facts in history long before he began to put in practice his
own clear thinking in his chosen
field, and to win the rewards that
come to the honest, frank, and fearless man whom the American people have come to respect and expect in public life. Indeed, while
he was here his fellow students and
his later fellow colleagues, Professors C. W. E. Miller and E. A.
Andrews, remember him as one/
among a very few who advocated'
the participation of college and
scientificaly trained men in public
service as their imperative obligation. He, ilke other Hopkins men,
assumed that duty, and has done his
part well, seeking only right and
Justice and asking neither fear nor
favor from any man. A single
small instance of the courage and
ingenuous candor of the man may
serve to illustrate this point. Shortly
after his nomination, when he must
have clearly understood the value
of every vote as well as the usual
sensitiveness of a corrupt community to any attempted reform of

its besetting sin, he prefaced a public address in that community as
follows:
"Gentlemen, it has been a custom
of mine when a thing ought to be
said, to say frankly what I think,
and I do not think I shall now begin to change that habit." Nor did
he. He told these people in that
address some of the most unpalatable but righteous things that I
have ever heard of being said in
that community.
Governor Wilson is not a narrow
pedagogue nor an emotional or visionary theorist. He is after facts,
not fads or fancies. He has perhaps had a broader and more liberal
training in the fundamentals of the
history and facts of government
than any of his predecessors in the
office of president. He is neither
a reactionary nor a radical, but a
sane, sensible, honest, and catholic
man, who is neither of the North
nor of the South nor of the West,
nor for one or the other of these
sections, but a man who, happily,
in his varied experience combines
and understands the people and interests of all these sections.
Born of Ohio parents, in Staunton, Va., reared in Georgia and
South Carolina, educated at Davidson in North Carolina, Princeton
in New Jersey, the University of
Virginia, and Johns Hopkins University in Maryland (in which latter he was fellow in history in 1884
and from which he graduated with
the Ph.D. degree in i886); an educator at Bryn Mawr College in
Pennsylvania, Wesleyan University
in Connecticut, Johns Hopkins in
Maryland, New York Law School
in New York, and Princeton University in New Jersey; an executive
in this University and in the State
of New Jersey; an author of numerous articles and books on government, history and literature; a
professor of history, of political
economy, of jurisprudence and politics, he is the product of and has
played a part in the better life of
a wide area of our common country, and has contributed liberally
and wisely to its political thought
and literature. The late Professor
Bourne of Yale University, when
reviewing Wilson's five - volume
"History of the American People"
(perhaps the best one we have, all
told, for the general reader), said
to me that he regarded it one of
the most valuable contributions to
American historical literature, be-

11, 1912.

cause "it treated Southern history
in such a way as not to offend the
Northerner, and Northern history
in such a way as not to offend the
Southerner." This same remark
might be made of his "Division and
Reunion," a brief and good history
of the United States from 1829 to
1909, which, as a standard college
text-book, has gone through several editions since its publication in.
1894. So also his book, "The
State: Elements of Historical and
Practical Politics" (1889), which
considers the facts and practice of
government in ancient as well as
modern nations, has proved a most
valuable aid to the political instruction of youth in. American schools
and colleges. In all of his work
the delightful personality and force
of the man who has been a teacher
of history not only for its truth
but the good that is in it is evident.
With something akin to historical
inspiration, if there be such a thing,
Wilson, while a graduate student
at the Johns Hopkins University,
grasped the significance of the
legislature in American constitutional development, and gave us in
his "Congressional Government, A
Study of Government By Committee," what has been called "the
first account ever given_of the way
Americans actually do govern themselves." This book, I am informed,
has but recently been adopted by
Harvard University as a text-book
in the course on Government superseding Bryce's "The American
Commonwealth," which has long
been regarded as the standard work
on this subject. It is not very
usual for a doctor's dissertation to
receive such high and well merited
honor.
There is another side to Governor Wilson that is not less admirable, though not so often noticed
in the harsh practice and carping
spirit of everyday life. This is the
essential kindliness and affectionate
loyalty of the man, which makes
him delightfully human. It speaks
for vitality not only of body and
head, but of heart. The dedication
of "Congressional Government,"
his first book, "To his father, the
patient guide of his youth, the precious companion of his manhood,
his best instructor and most lenient
critic ;" and that of his last and
most ambitious work, "A History
of the American People," "To
E. A. W., in loving acknowledgement of gentle benefits which can
neither be • measured nor repaid,"
are not only gracious in expression,
and in sentiment, but are evidences
of that spirit which in any man,
great or small, makes him greater.
Though Governor Wilson is physically a thin and scholarly lodking
man, a sort of lean dog for a long

PENOLOGISTS MEET HERE
American Prison Association Holding
Meetings in McCoy Hail—Convention
Combines Business and Pleasure.

The annual meeting of the American Prison Association is being held
this year in Baltimore, from November 9 to 14. The meetings, the
object of which is to discuss prison
methods and management, take
place in McCoy Hall.
The congress is attended by upwards of six hundred delegates.
Among this number are many
prominent penologists and practical
prison administrators. The visiting
delegates will be entertained in a
manner consistent with Baltimore's
far-famed reputation for hospitality. The local Committee of Arrangements, of which Joseph N.Ulman is chairman, and Charles D.
Reid, secretary, has chosen fifty
members of the Association to act
as a reception coMmittee. President Remsen was requested to serve
as a member of this committee, and
he has accepted the invitation. Dr.
Howard A. Kelly is the chairman
of this committee.
The opening meeting of this year's
session was held at 3 o'clock, Saturday, November 9. The Association
will continue in session until next
Thursday. The program of the
meetings provided for an informal
reception .at McCoy Hall on last
Saturday evening, and practically
all of Tuesday, November 12, will
be given over to the social entertainment of the delegates.
race type, and no match in size for
his distinguished late antagonists,
who, as every one realizes, are
large men not only in physique, he
has "a way with him" something
like diminutive "Old Aunt Nancy."
When this dusky old Southerner
was hustled and jostled by the
crowd at the circus or camp-meeting, she had a way of jabbing her
sharp elbows into other people's
ribs, and would go through the
crowd with a Yale rush, remarking, "I'm . mighty little, I knows,
but, 0 Lordy!" This is one of his
own good stories, and worth retelling.
As the successor of a long line of
distinguished predecessors, it seems
fitting that the mantle of those
great Democrats, Jefferson, Madison, Jackson, and Cleveland, should
fall upon Woodrow Wilson, and at
least one hundred and twelve out
of one hundred and eighteen who
were approached of the staff of the
University that is proud to call him
her son feel that they, irrespective
of their party allignments, honored
themselves in voting, or working
foi his success.

THE MADISON

Johns Hopkins practically lost
any claim it might have had on the
State championship Saturday at
Homewood when the Western
Maryland College eleven defeated the Black and Blue, 13 to 6.
The 'Varsity Was in a patched-up
condition, one-third of the team being composed of substitute players.
Ben Tappan was not at quarterback
on account of an infected arm,
Dewey and George Penniman could
not play because of a death in the
family, and Nagle is still troubled
by a knee that was badly bruised in
the game with Stevens the Saturday previous. While the men who
replaced these players did'excellent
work, it is obvious that Hopkins
would have made a much better
showing had the regular players
been in the line-up.
The Westminster team, on the
other hand, was in excellent condition. The up-Staters consider the
Hopkins game their most important
contest, and for two weeks Coaches
Twigg and Sprague had worked
their team to the limit. A number
of puzzling trick plays were made
especially for the game, two of
which on two different occasions

figured directly in Western Maryland's scoring. One of them, too,
was used by the team last year
when it defeated Hopkins, 6 to o.
The play was an adaptation of the
old "Minnesota shift"—the entire
line shifting to one side of center.
The Carroll countians used the play
frequently, but the 'Varsity caught
on to it, and the last time the shift
was used only two yards were
(rained.
It some tactics of the game, Hopkins men were superior.
La
Motte's punts were decidedly better than Bowers', and Branham and
Liebensperg-er excelled in tackling.
Referee Land inflicted numerous
penalties, the majority falling to
Western Maryland. Had they not.
received so many it is probable that
both teams would have scored more
points.
The first quarter showed flashes
of brilliant playing on Hopkins'
part. Hopkins lost the ball on a
fumble on the 'Western Maryland
30-yard line, and Capt. Weaver recovering it started down field for a
touchdown. He had a clear field for
the 70-yard run, but Catlin started
out after him, catching up when
Weaver was five yards from goal
line. It would have been useless to
tackle because Weaver could have
slid over with the ball. Catlin

Notice.

The Arbitration-Literary Society
offers every year a medal to the
freshman writing the best paper on
some peace subject. This year the
choice of the subject will be left
entirely with the individual contestants. There arc no requirements
other than being a member of the
Society. Those who are interested
in the matter should speak with
Carl J. Weber, '14.

Alumni Magazine.

The Medical Standard Book Co.

The first issue of the Johns Hopkins Alumni Magazine is now in
press and will appear in a few days.
This magazine is the result of a
movement among the alumni of the
University as represented by the
Alumni Association. Last year the
project was started and a committee of editors was appointed to publish the magazine, to be the official
organ of the Alumni Association.
The Board of Editors consists of
Prof. W. W. Willoughby, Dr. B.
C. Steiner, Prof. W. P. Mustard,
Mr. H. Findlay French, Dr. Evelyth
Bridgman, Dr. W. W. Ford and
Mr. Theodore Straus, all of whom
are well known to the members of
the University. Mr. Lawrence C.
Wroth, A. B. '05, is the managing
editor under whose direction the
magazine is being published.
In form, the magazine will be
a paper-covered volume of the ordinary magazine size. There will be
continued articles of general interest, as well as articles of news
from the various University departments.
It will be published four times
during the academic year and
will appear in November, January,
March and May. The price of subscription is one dollar per year.
The object of the alumni magazine is to keep the alumni in touch
with University affairs by a magazine essentially their own. It is to
organize and solidify the body of
the alumni and to make them as a
unit, able to bring their influence to
bear for the benefit of the University.

'Varsity Scrubs Win.

Last Friday at Homewood the
'Varsity "Scrubs" played Marston's
University School. Although the
"Scrubs" won by the score of 13-6,
they did not make a very good
showing. It is true that the most
of Marston's team, man for man,
weighed about as much as their
opponents, but one or two positions
on the line, where lack of heavy
candidates forced in a very light
player, were naturally, very weak.
Hopkins had the advantage in that
their line held strongly, but Lovelace of Marston's seemed able to
make good distance around the ends
because of his speed and weight.
He played the best game of either
side.
No scoring was done by the teams
until the last quarter; in fact, up
until that time neither team had had
a decided advantage. A number of
forward passes were tried, and these
were the cause of the last two goals.
Strange to say, each of the forward
passes resulting in sc9res were made
by the defense intercepting a pass
—first Richardson of the "Scrubs"
got away, and then Lovelace of
Marston's. Knipp at quarter made
several good tackles for Hopkins.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 11, 1912
The Cotillon Situation.

The turn which the cotillon affair
has taken during the last few days
is much to be regretted. It is
understood that the Student Council and the Cotillon Board, unable
to reach any agreement with regard
to non-fraternity membership on
the Board, have definitely broken
off negotiations. The Student Council conceded as much as it felt the
interests of the non-fraternity men
would permit, and finding the Cotillon Board still obstinate, has now
turned the case over to the nonfraternity men themselves, with the
recommendation that they take
whatever steps they deem advisable
to gain "their point. The purpose
of a body like the Student Council
is to mediate, and when, for one
reason or another, mediation fails
and a policy of active partizanship
becomes necessary, it must turn
over its case to some partizan
agency. It is understood that the
non-fraternity men have appointed
a committee to present their demands to the Cotillon Board.
The policy of the Cotillon Board
in its negotiations with the Student
Council has been, to say the least,
extremely short-sighted. In order
that the whole question might be
settled amicably and without any
bad feeling, the Council showed
itself ready to concede far beyond
the half-way point, but the Board
on its side stubbornly refused to
yield an inch. Consequently, if
any unpleasant results arise, which
might have been averted by the
exercise (if a little common sense
and common reasonableness, the
Board will have nobody but itself
to thank for them. THE NEWSLETTER wishes to be fair to both
sides; and the only way in which
we can be so is to review in a brief
fashion the history of the negotiations.
At the very beginning, the Student Council proposed that in addition to the present six fraternity
delegates, there should be four nonfraternity delegates to the Cotillon
Board, one to be chosen by the nonfraternity men of each of the four
classes. In the basic character of
this proposal the Council displayed

its conciliatory attitude. There is Most completeI FALL SUITINGS f in the city now on

The Cotillon Question.

November 10, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Several weeks ago I
wrote a letter giving my reasons
why I thought that the non-fraternity men should have representation on the Cotillon Board. My
reasons why the Cotillon Board and
all the fraternity men should consent to this representation were as
follows: (I) Consenting to this
representation is showing the nonfraternity men due courtesy; (2) it
Is granting them what is just; (3)
and it will make the cotillons more
truly Hopkins dances. As a result
of my letter, many fellows, both
fraternity and non-fraternity, came
to me and expressed their agreement with me. The Student Council, moreover, took up the question
with the Cotillon Board, as it is
at present constituted, and urged

'4.11111i1111111111111 1111i1111""

101-

that they grant the non-fraternity
men four representatives, to be
chosen by the non-fraternity men.
The fact that the Student Council
asked for as many as four representatives, as against six of the
fraternity• men, seems perhaps surprising, but when we realize that
the non-fraternity men, including
the first year class, far outnumber
the fraternity men, and, excluding
the first year class, lack only two of
having a majority, it does not seem
at all surprising.
However, the Cotillon Board rejected the proposal of the Student
Council and offered, in its stead, to
give the non-fraternity men one
representative to be selected by the
Cotillon Board itself. The members of the Cotillon Board further
specified that that man would be selected who was the "most worthy."
If, instead of discussing how the
Cotillon Board should be constituted, we were discussing how we
should distribute a few alms among
the needy, the words "most worthy"
would be extremely appropriate,
but, in the case at hand, the nonfraternity men took offense at them,
and I cannot blame the non-fraternity men. Moreover, the nonfraternity men had asked for representation, and they vigorously op •
posed a proposal for a pretense at
representation.

We now come to the second
phase of this agitation. I, among
others, urged the Student Council
to make concessions, in order that
we might avoid ill feeling and hastily bring this subject to an amicable conclusion. The Student Council then made its first concession.
They made a proposal that the nonfraternity men should have only
t,wo representatives, those two to be
elected by the non-fraternity men.
This proposal also the Cotillon
Board rejected. Then the Student
Council, after having again been
urged by some men to do all that
was possible to bring the question
to a peaceful close, made a second
concession. This was that there
should be two representatives elected only by those non-fraternity
men who had, by November 15,
paid their subscription for the first
cotillon. The Cotillon Board rejected this proposal also. The Student Council, after some deliberation, then made a third concession to
the effect that there should, in any
case be one representative, and, in
case twenty-five. non-fraternity men
subscribed for the first -cotillon, there
should be two, but never over two.
This last proposal the Cotillon
Board also rejected.
The Student Council has, by its
repeated concessions, shown that it
is eagerly in favor of having the
question settled peaceably. It has
been affected by two things—on the
one hand, its desire for peace, and,
on the other, honor. It has made
three concessions because of a desire for peace. It has made its last
concession because of honor.
Moreover, the Student Council
is taking up a question which affects
almost a majority of the members
of the three upper clasess, those
members who are not fraternity
men. The Student Council is
obliged to listen to the complaints
of these men who are so great
in numbers. Some of these men
have, in •the past week, urged the
Student Council to concede everything that could honorably be conceded. Others have become militant. All feel that now no more
concessions can honorably be made.
They feel that they have not been
met half way in their eagerness
to settle the question amicably.
They feel that their eagerness has
been met by indifference.
The non-fraternity men, up to the
'present time, have done nothing
formally, except to make proposals
to be rejected. These proposals
were due largely to the men who
subjected their pride to a desire for
peace. The peaceful men have had
their turn and have accomplished
nothing except to get from the
Cotillon Board the statement that
on Monday, the eleventh, the Board
would go ahead to work on the
cotillon. The peaceful men, who
before had tried to keep the militant men in the background, are
now ready to yield to them. If
radical steps are now to be taken,
the one will work with the other.
Yours truly,
J. EARLn UHLER.

Early Start for Baseball.

Football Massmeating.

Contracts for a baseball game
with the University of Virginia to
be played at Charlottesville, on
Wednesday, March 26, have just
been signed by Manager C. Leland
Getz, of the 'Varsity baseball game.
The date in question is the Wednesday after Easter, and the last date
of the Easter holidays. At least
three games will be played at home
durinfr the Easter holidays before
the 'Varsity nine leaves for Charlottesville.
This will be the first time that
a game has been al-fanged between
Hopkins and Virginia since baseball was officially recognized by the
Hopkins Athletic Board in 1910,
and it is to be hoped that the baseball relations now commenced between these two institutions may
be of a long continued and agreeable nature. Hopkins has asked
for a return game at Homewood
for the spring of 1914:
Manager Getz has been literally
swamped with offers of baseball
games. The baseball schedule is

"It is a duty and a privilege for
every Hopkins man to join the
cheering section at the forthcoming
games," were the words Dr. Magoffin addressed to the mass-meeting on Friday last.
"To give all the aid within our
power to the team is our duty,
obviously enough," lie continued,
"and it is a privilege to co-operate
with a team that is so loyal and
persevering. Moreover, it must be
borne in mind that the team is composed largely of new men," he said,
"not old football veterans, thoroughly trained. This is just the beginning of a great team. And with
our help in these next games, it
will convince us of its greatness."
Assistant Coach Fulton then spoke
from the standpoint of one who
"has been there," of the stimulus
to vigorOns effort upon the field,
which comes from vigorous cheering in the stands.
The meeting was concluded by
practice in the songs and yells, led
by "Buts" Sutton.

BOX 554,
CHICAGO, ILL., Nov. 7, 1912.
HON: HARRY C. BURGAN, Graduate Mana' ger, Football Team, Johns Hopkins
University, Baltimore, Md.
DEAR SIR—We have one particularly
beautiful skunk which it seems a pity
to kill for market as it has become quite
a pet. We removed the scent sacs when
Young so. no skunk odor is possible.
Would not this pet make a great mascot for the games? It could be exhibited
aloft in a bird cage before and during
the play. With its expensive fur coat it
too would enjoy the sport.
We will let you have it for $15 if
You would enjoy having something absolutely novel. It likes to be petted.
If interested, please reply at once.
Very truly yours,

RUBAIYAT Op

much mirth during the past few
days among Graduate Manager
Burgan's coterie of managers and
assistants. Although the offer has
not yet been accepted, it has caused
much comment and many suggestions have been made.
Several whom have read the letter have expressed their doubts
about the second.. sentence of the
letter, and it has been suggested
that it would be well to secure
statistics from the economics department in regard to the pbssible

also may be in a position to throw
some valuable light on the subject.

worth to the track team:

authorized to get into communication with the Skunk Development

A No. i first-class skunk for use
in the track practice.
It is thought that the speed of
both the sprinters and distance men
might be materially increased if it
could be so arranged that the skunk
should chase them in practice several times a week.
1915 Hullabaloo Election.

At the sophomore class meeting
last Tuesday week, J. Saulsbury
Short was selected to be editor-inchief of the 1915 Hullabaloo. Four
men were nominated at the previous
meeting; but two withdrew their
names, leaving Short and Clive
Nicholson in the race. Emmette
R. Spencer was chosen business
manager with Millard Eiseman and
Nicholson for assistants. Other
editors will selected at a later meeting.
David J. G. Hutzler was elected
to be the 1915 representative on
the Student Council Board. Sewall was made class historian.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVII, NO. 6.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER

HOPKINS MAN PRESIDENT
Woodrow Wilson the Son of Many States and Many Institutions of
Learning, but Hopkins Claims a Share at Least of the
Honor Which Has Accrued to One of Her Ph. D.'s.
Woodrow Wilson, of Virginia,
Georgia, South Carolina, Maryland
and New Jersey, will be the eighth
president of the United States born
in the Old Dominion, that mother
of States and statesmen. He will
be the ninth Scotch-Irishman and
the first Johns Hopkins man upon
Whom the people of the United
States have conferred this high
honor and to whom they have confided this great trust. Yet he is
a man that belongs to no one small
locality, nor section, nor university.
For many States and schools have
had a part in his making, and he
is •a typical American of the substantial Scotch and English. stock
which furnished a large percentage
of eighteenth century immigration
to America and became so prominent in the winning of American
freedom. In a sense he may be
,said to epitomize the high moral
ideals arid purpose of the men and
women of the twentieth century,
and he has demonstrated, in his
person the power of progressive reform in politics in a State that had
developed some of the worst features of "practical politics" as
manipulated by the "boss."
Here in Baltimore, however, we
have always claimed him as a
"Hopkins man," and we were proud'
to do so because of his record as
a teacher of the 'science of politics
and the author of good books on
political facts in history long before he began to put in practice his
own clear thinking in his chosen
field, and to win the rewards that
come to the honest, frank, and fearless man whom the American people have come to respect and expect in public life. Indeed, while
he was here his fellow students and
his later fellow colleagues, Professors C. W. E. Miller and E. A.
Andrews, remember him as one/
among a very few who advocated'
the participation of college and
scientificaly trained men in public
service as their imperative obligation. He, ilke other Hopkins men,
assumed that duty, and has done his
part well, seeking only right and
Justice and asking neither fear nor
favor from any man. A single
small instance of the courage and
ingenuous candor of the man may
serve to illustrate this point. Shortly
after his nomination, when he must
have clearly understood the value
of every vote as well as the usual
sensitiveness of a corrupt community to any attempted reform of

its besetting sin, he prefaced a public address in that community as
follows:
"Gentlemen, it has been a custom
of mine when a thing ought to be
said, to say frankly what I think,
and I do not think I shall now begin to change that habit." Nor did
he. He told these people in that
address some of the most unpalatable but righteous things that I
have ever heard of being said in
that community.
Governor Wilson is not a narrow
pedagogue nor an emotional or visionary theorist. He is after facts,
not fads or fancies. He has perhaps had a broader and more liberal
training in the fundamentals of the
history and facts of government
than any of his predecessors in the
office of president. He is neither
a reactionary nor a radical, but a
sane, sensible, honest, and catholic
man, who is neither of the North
nor of the South nor of the West,
nor for one or the other of these
sections, but a man who, happily,
in his varied experience combines
and understands the people and interests of all these sections.
Born of Ohio parents, in Staunton, Va., reared in Georgia and
South Carolina, educated at Davidson in North Carolina, Princeton
in New Jersey, the University of
Virginia, and Johns Hopkins University in Maryland (in which latter he was fellow in history in 1884
and from which he graduated with
the Ph.D. degree in i886); an educator at Bryn Mawr College in
Pennsylvania, Wesleyan University
in Connecticut, Johns Hopkins in
Maryland, New York Law School
in New York, and Princeton University in New Jersey; an executive
in this University and in the State
of New Jersey; an author of numerous articles and books on government, history and literature; a
professor of history, of political
economy, of jurisprudence and politics, he is the product of and has
played a part in the better life of
a wide area of our common country, and has contributed liberally
and wisely to its political thought
and literature. The late Professor
Bourne of Yale University, when
reviewing Wilson's five - volume
"History of the American People"
(perhaps the best one we have, all
told, for the general reader), said
to me that he regarded it one of
the most valuable contributions to
American historical literature, be-

11, 1912.

cause "it treated Southern history
in such a way as not to offend the
Northerner, and Northern history
in such a way as not to offend the
Southerner." This same remark
might be made of his "Division and
Reunion," a brief and good history
of the United States from 1829 to
1909, which, as a standard college
text-book, has gone through several editions since its publication in.
1894. So also his book, "The
State: Elements of Historical and
Practical Politics" (1889), which
considers the facts and practice of
government in ancient as well as
modern nations, has proved a most
valuable aid to the political instruction of youth in. American schools
and colleges. In all of his work
the delightful personality and force
of the man who has been a teacher
of history not only for its truth
but the good that is in it is evident.
With something akin to historical
inspiration, if there be such a thing,
Wilson, while a graduate student
at the Johns Hopkins University,
grasped the significance of the
legislature in American constitutional development, and gave us in
his "Congressional Government, A
Study of Government By Committee," what has been called "the
first account ever given_of the way
Americans actually do govern themselves." This book, I am informed,
has but recently been adopted by
Harvard University as a text-book
in the course on Government superseding Bryce's "The American
Commonwealth," which has long
been regarded as the standard work
on this subject. It is not very
usual for a doctor's dissertation to
receive such high and well merited
honor.
There is another side to Governor Wilson that is not less admirable, though not so often noticed
in the harsh practice and carping
spirit of everyday life. This is the
essential kindliness and affectionate
loyalty of the man, which makes
him delightfully human. It speaks
for vitality not only of body and
head, but of heart. The dedication
of "Congressional Government,"
his first book, "To his father, the
patient guide of his youth, the precious companion of his manhood,
his best instructor and most lenient
critic ;" and that of his last and
most ambitious work, "A History
of the American People," "To
E. A. W., in loving acknowledgement of gentle benefits which can
neither be • measured nor repaid,"
are not only gracious in expression,
and in sentiment, but are evidences
of that spirit which in any man,
great or small, makes him greater.
Though Governor Wilson is physically a thin and scholarly lodking
man, a sort of lean dog for a long

PENOLOGISTS MEET HERE
American Prison Association Holding
Meetings in McCoy Hail—Convention
Combines Business and Pleasure.

The annual meeting of the American Prison Association is being held
this year in Baltimore, from November 9 to 14. The meetings, the
object of which is to discuss prison
methods and management, take
place in McCoy Hall.
The congress is attended by upwards of six hundred delegates.
Among this number are many
prominent penologists and practical
prison administrators. The visiting
delegates will be entertained in a
manner consistent with Baltimore's
far-famed reputation for hospitality. The local Committee of Arrangements, of which Joseph N.Ulman is chairman, and Charles D.
Reid, secretary, has chosen fifty
members of the Association to act
as a reception coMmittee. President Remsen was requested to serve
as a member of this committee, and
he has accepted the invitation. Dr.
Howard A. Kelly is the chairman
of this committee.
The opening meeting of this year's
session was held at 3 o'clock, Saturday, November 9. The Association
will continue in session until next
Thursday. The program of the
meetings provided for an informal
reception .at McCoy Hall on last
Saturday evening, and practically
all of Tuesday, November 12, will
be given over to the social entertainment of the delegates.

who, as every one realizes, are

has "a way with him" something

When this dusky old Southerner

As the successor of a long line of

fall upon Woodrow Wilson, and at

foi his success.

Johns Hopkins practically lost
any claim it might have had on the
State championship Saturday at
Homewood when the Western
Maryland College eleven defeated the Black and Blue, 13 to 6.
The 'Varsity Was in a patched-up
condition, one-third of the team being composed of substitute players.
Ben Tappan was not at quarterback
on account of an infected arm,
Dewey and George Penniman could
not play because of a death in the
family, and Nagle is still troubled
by a knee that was badly bruised in
the game with Stevens the Saturday previous. While the men who
replaced these players did'excellent
work, it is obvious that Hopkins
would have made a much better
showing had the regular players
been in the line-up.
The Westminster team, on the
other hand, was in excellent condition. The up-Staters consider the
Hopkins game their most important
contest, and for two weeks Coaches
Twigg and Sprague had worked
their team to the limit. A number
of puzzling trick plays were made
especially for the game, two of
which on two different occasions

figured directly in Western Maryland's scoring. One of them, too,
was used by the team last year
when it defeated Hopkins, 6 to o.
The play was an adaptation of the
old "Minnesota shift"—the entire
line shifting to one side of center.
The Carroll countians used the play
frequently, but the 'Varsity caught
on to it, and the last time the shift
was used only two yards were
(rained.
It some tactics of the game, Hopkins men were superior.
La
Motte's punts were decidedly better than Bowers', and Branham and
Liebensperg-er excelled in tackling.
Referee Land inflicted numerous
penalties, the majority falling to
Western Maryland. Had they not.
received so many it is probable that
both teams would have scored more
points.
The first quarter showed flashes
of brilliant playing on Hopkins'
part. Hopkins lost the ball on a
fumble on the 'Western Maryland
30-yard line, and Capt. Weaver recovering it started down field for a
touchdown. He had a clear field for
the 70-yard run, but Catlin started
out after him, catching up when
Weaver was five yards from goal
line. It would have been useless to
tackle because Weaver could have
slid over with the ball. Catlin

Alumni Magazine.

The Medical Standard Book Co.

The first issue of the Johns Hopkins Alumni Magazine is now in
press and will appear in a few days.
This magazine is the result of a
movement among the alumni of the
University as represented by the
Alumni Association. Last year the
project was started and a committee of editors was appointed to publish the magazine, to be the official
organ of the Alumni Association.
The Board of Editors consists of
Prof. W. W. Willoughby, Dr. B.
C. Steiner, Prof. W. P. Mustard,
Mr. H. Findlay French, Dr. Evelyth
Bridgman, Dr. W. W. Ford and
Mr. Theodore Straus, all of whom
are well known to the members of
the University. Mr. Lawrence C.
Wroth, A. B. '05, is the managing
editor under whose direction the
magazine is being published.
In form, the magazine will be
a paper-covered volume of the ordinary magazine size. There will be
continued articles of general interest, as well as articles of news
from the various University departments.
It will be published four times
during the academic year and
will appear in November, January,
March and May. The price of subscription is one dollar per year.
The object of the alumni magazine is to keep the alumni in touch
with University affairs by a magazine essentially their own. It is to
organize and solidify the body of
the alumni and to make them as a
unit, able to bring their influence to
bear for the benefit of the University.

'Varsity Scrubs Win.

Last Friday at Homewood the
'Varsity "Scrubs" played Marston's
University School. Although the
"Scrubs" won by the score of 13-6,
they did not make a very good
showing. It is true that the most
of Marston's team, man for man,
weighed about as much as their
opponents, but one or two positions
on the line, where lack of heavy
candidates forced in a very light
player, were naturally, very weak.
Hopkins had the advantage in that
their line held strongly, but Lovelace of Marston's seemed able to
make good distance around the ends
because of his speed and weight.
He played the best game of either
side.
No scoring was done by the teams
until the last quarter; in fact, up
until that time neither team had had
a decided advantage. A number of
forward passes were tried, and these
were the cause of the last two goals.
Strange to say, each of the forward
passes resulting in sc9res were made
by the defense intercepting a pass
—first Richardson of the "Scrubs"
got away, and then Lovelace of
Marston's. Knipp at quarter made
several good tackles for Hopkins.

The Cotillon Situation.

The turn which the cotillon affair
has taken during the last few days
is much to be regretted. It is
understood that the Student Council and the Cotillon Board, unable
to reach any agreement with regard
to non-fraternity membership on
the Board, have definitely broken
off negotiations. The Student Council conceded as much as it felt the
interests of the non-fraternity men
would permit, and finding the Cotillon Board still obstinate, has now
turned the case over to the nonfraternity men themselves, with the
recommendation that they take
whatever steps they deem advisable
to gain "their point. The purpose
of a body like the Student Council
is to mediate, and when, for one
reason or another, mediation fails
and a policy of active partizanship
becomes necessary, it must turn
over its case to some partizan
agency. It is understood that the
non-fraternity men have appointed
a committee to present their demands to the Cotillon Board.
The policy of the Cotillon Board
in its negotiations with the Student
Council has been, to say the least,
extremely short-sighted. In order
that the whole question might be
settled amicably and without any
bad feeling, the Council showed
itself ready to concede far beyond
the half-way point, but the Board
on its side stubbornly refused to
yield an inch. Consequently, if
any unpleasant results arise, which
might have been averted by the
exercise (if a little common sense
and common reasonableness, the
Board will have nobody but itself
to thank for them. THE NEWSLETTER wishes to be fair to both
sides; and the only way in which
we can be so is to review in a brief
fashion the history of the negotiations.
At the very beginning, the Student Council proposed that in addition to the present six fraternity
delegates, there should be four nonfraternity delegates to the Cotillon
Board, one to be chosen by the nonfraternity men of each of the four
classes. In the basic character of
this proposal the Council displayed

The Cotillon Question.

November 10, 1912.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:
Dear Sir—Several weeks ago I
wrote a letter giving my reasons
why I thought that the non-fraternity men should have representation on the Cotillon Board. My
reasons why the Cotillon Board and
all the fraternity men should consent to this representation were as
follows: (I) Consenting to this
representation is showing the nonfraternity men due courtesy; (2) it
Is granting them what is just; (3)
and it will make the cotillons more
truly Hopkins dances. As a result
of my letter, many fellows, both
fraternity and non-fraternity, came
to me and expressed their agreement with me. The Student Council, moreover, took up the question
with the Cotillon Board, as it is
at present constituted, and urged

'4.11111i1111111111111 1111i1111""

101-

that they grant the non-fraternity
men four representatives, to be
chosen by the non-fraternity men.
The fact that the Student Council
asked for as many as four representatives, as against six of the
fraternity• men, seems perhaps surprising, but when we realize that
the non-fraternity men, including
the first year class, far outnumber
the fraternity men, and, excluding
the first year class, lack only two of
having a majority, it does not seem
at all surprising.
However, the Cotillon Board rejected the proposal of the Student
Council and offered, in its stead, to
give the non-fraternity men one
representative to be selected by the
Cotillon Board itself. The members of the Cotillon Board further
specified that that man would be selected who was the "most worthy."
If, instead of discussing how the
Cotillon Board should be constituted, we were discussing how we
should distribute a few alms among
the needy, the words "most worthy"
would be extremely appropriate,
but, in the case at hand, the nonfraternity men took offense at them,
and I cannot blame the non-fraternity men. Moreover, the nonfraternity men had asked for representation, and they vigorously op •
posed a proposal for a pretense at
representation.

We now come to the second
phase of this agitation. I, among
others, urged the Student Council
to make concessions, in order that
we might avoid ill feeling and hastily bring this subject to an amicable conclusion. The Student Council then made its first concession.
They made a proposal that the nonfraternity men should have only
t,wo representatives, those two to be
elected by the non-fraternity men.
This proposal also the Cotillon
Board rejected. Then the Student
Council, after having again been
urged by some men to do all that
was possible to bring the question
to a peaceful close, made a second
concession. This was that there
should be two representatives elected only by those non-fraternity
men who had, by November 15,
paid their subscription for the first
cotillon. The Cotillon Board rejected this proposal also. The Student Council, after some deliberation, then made a third concession to
the effect that there should, in any
case be one representative, and, in
case twenty-five. non-fraternity men
subscribed for the first -cotillon, there
should be two, but never over two.
This last proposal the Cotillon
Board also rejected.
The Student Council has, by its
repeated concessions, shown that it
is eagerly in favor of having the
question settled peaceably. It has
been affected by two things—on the
one hand, its desire for peace, and,
on the other, honor. It has made
three concessions because of a desire for peace. It has made its last
concession because of honor.
Moreover, the Student Council
is taking up a question which affects
almost a majority of the members
of the three upper clasess, those
members who are not fraternity
men. The Student Council is
obliged to listen to the complaints
of these men who are so great
in numbers. Some of these men
have, in •the past week, urged the
Student Council to concede everything that could honorably be conceded. Others have become militant. All feel that now no more
concessions can honorably be made.
They feel that they have not been
met half way in their eagerness
to settle the question amicably.
They feel that their eagerness has
been met by indifference.
The non-fraternity men, up to the
'present time, have done nothing
formally, except to make proposals
to be rejected. These proposals
were due largely to the men who
subjected their pride to a desire for
peace. The peaceful men have had
their turn and have accomplished
nothing except to get from the
Cotillon Board the statement that
on Monday, the eleventh, the Board
would go ahead to work on the
cotillon. The peaceful men, who
before had tried to keep the militant men in the background, are
now ready to yield to them. If
radical steps are now to be taken,
the one will work with the other.
Yours truly,
J. EARLn UHLER.

Early Start for Baseball.

Football Massmeating.

Contracts for a baseball game
with the University of Virginia to
be played at Charlottesville, on
Wednesday, March 26, have just
been signed by Manager C. Leland
Getz, of the 'Varsity baseball game.
The date in question is the Wednesday after Easter, and the last date
of the Easter holidays. At least
three games will be played at home
durinfr the Easter holidays before
the 'Varsity nine leaves for Charlottesville.
This will be the first time that
a game has been al-fanged between
Hopkins and Virginia since baseball was officially recognized by the
Hopkins Athletic Board in 1910,
and it is to be hoped that the baseball relations now commenced between these two institutions may
be of a long continued and agreeable nature. Hopkins has asked
for a return game at Homewood
for the spring of 1914:
Manager Getz has been literally
swamped with offers of baseball
games. The baseball schedule is

"It is a duty and a privilege for
every Hopkins man to join the
cheering section at the forthcoming
games," were the words Dr. Magoffin addressed to the mass-meeting on Friday last.
"To give all the aid within our
power to the team is our duty,
obviously enough," lie continued,
"and it is a privilege to co-operate
with a team that is so loyal and
persevering. Moreover, it must be
borne in mind that the team is composed largely of new men," he said,
"not old football veterans, thoroughly trained. This is just the beginning of a great team. And with
our help in these next games, it
will convince us of its greatness."
Assistant Coach Fulton then spoke
from the standpoint of one who
"has been there," of the stimulus
to vigorOns effort upon the field,
which comes from vigorous cheering in the stands.
The meeting was concluded by
practice in the songs and yells, led
by "Buts" Sutton.

BOX 554,
CHICAGO, ILL., Nov. 7, 1912.
HON: HARRY C. BURGAN, Graduate Mana' ger, Football Team, Johns Hopkins
University, Baltimore, Md.
DEAR SIR—We have one particularly
beautiful skunk which it seems a pity
to kill for market as it has become quite
a pet. We removed the scent sacs when
Young so. no skunk odor is possible.
Would not this pet make a great mascot for the games? It could be exhibited
aloft in a bird cage before and during
the play. With its expensive fur coat it
too would enjoy the sport.
We will let you have it for $15 if
You would enjoy having something absolutely novel. It likes to be petted.
If interested, please reply at once.
Very truly yours,

RUBAIYAT Op

letter, and it has been suggested
that it would be well to secure
statistics from the economics department in regard to the pbssible

some valuable light on the subject.

1915 Hullabaloo Election.

At the sophomore class meeting
last Tuesday week, J. Saulsbury
Short was selected to be editor-inchief of the 1915 Hullabaloo. Four
men were nominated at the previous
meeting; but two withdrew their
names, leaving Short and Clive
Nicholson in the race. Emmette
R. Spencer was chosen business
manager with Millard Eiseman and
Nicholson for assistants. Other
editors will selected at a later meeting.
David J. G. Hutzler was elected
to be the 1915 representative on
the Student Council Board. Sewall was made class historian.
